titleStmt.title: A Sketch of the Past - Segment 5
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

sourceDesc.p: Woolf, Virginia. “A Sketch of the Past (TS.A.5.a,1-69).” 1939-41. Monks House Papers, University of Sussex, Sussex.
Woolf, Virginia. “A Sketch of the Past (MS.A.5.b-A.5.d): Reminiscences of Family and Childhood by Virginia Woolf.” 1939-41. Monks House Papers, University of Sussex, Sussex.

encodingDesc.p: This is a diachronic test encoding produced by Hans Walter Gabler, Volker Zapf and Joshua Schäuble in the course of the DFG/NEH funded project "Diachronic Markup and Presentation Practices for Text Editions in Digital Research Environments". Fruther documentation on this encoding can be found on the project GitHub.

body.p:
I was thinking, as I crossed the channel
Cahnell Chanell last night , of Stella; thinking in a very jerky disconnected way , ; with
the boat train arriving , ;
people talking loudly,
quarrelling outside the door;
chains
being dropped, and the screws the beginning,
clanking; and the steamer
suddenly hooting. Th i e se
giving those sudden stertorous snorts. And
as
on as
the first morning after a broken night is distracted instead of beginning Roger again,
(as I ought) as I ought, I will write what down some of my distracted and disconnected thoughts . ; to serve, should the time come, for notes.

And How many people are there now
who could still able to
think about Stella on the 20th June 1939? Very few. Jack is dead. died last Christmas; George and Gerald are dead. a year or two ago;
Kitty Maxse and Margaret Massingberd have been dead
for many years. many years now.
Susan Lushington and the Stillmans Lisa Stillman are still alive . ; but how they live and where I know not.
Anyone Perhaps my thus I think of her less disconnectedly and more truly than anyone now living, save for Vanessa and Adrian , ; and perhaps old Sophie Farrell. She was the only daughter of the handsome barrister Herbert Duckworth;
I
L But
Of her childhood I know practically nothing. She was the only daughter of the handsome barrister Herbert Duckworth ; and , but as he died when she was 3 or 4 three or four . She did not remember him:
She she did not remember him, or those years when
my her mother was as happy as anyone can be. I think, from stray anecdotes, that she and from what I observed noticed myself, that when she came to consciousness when as a child the unhappy years were at their height. That would account for some qualities in Stella. Her first memories of her mother were of a very sad
widow widowed mother , going who "went about
doing good , in " -- Stella wished to have that on the tombstone -- visiting the slums, visiting too the Cancer hospital Hospi- tal in the Brompton Road. (This I knew she did: one case she saw "shocked" her she told our Quaker Aunt) Our Quaker Aunt told me that 2 this was her habit; for she said how one case there had "shocked her". Thus Stella grew up as a child was lived in the shade of that widowhood; saw that beautiful crape veiled figure daily; and perhaps then rece ad took then the ply which that was so marked -- a that attitude of devotion, almost canine , in its touching adoration
to her mother : a ; that passive, suffering affection; and a also that
complete dependance unquestioning dependance.
They were
the Sun sun and moon to each other : ; my mother the definite and positive;
Stella the reflecting, and satellite. My mother was stern with to her. Once All her devotion was given to George, who was like his father : ; and her care was for Gerald, born post umously and very delicate. Stella she snubbed -- treated severely;
so much so that before their marriage my father
protested. ventured a protest.
And she She replied that it might be true : ;
it was she was severe hard on Stella ,
because she felt Stella part of herself. "part of myself."
A pale silent child, I imagine her; sensitive , ; modest , ;
uncomplaining; She was not clever. very domestic, buried
caring only, I think, to help; in the home;
so completely unambitious, and yet so
adoring her mother, thinking only how she could help her, and without any ambition or even character of her own. And yet she had character. Very gentle, - so very modest,
honest, and in some way so individual
sensitive that -- so
she always made her own impression on people.
-- was
had friends Her friends , Friends, like Kitty Lushington, who, much more brilliant, Maxse, the brilliant the sparkling loved her with a real laughing tenderness for her own sake. The
This Her charm , -- was great; it was came
partly from this modesty, partly from this honesty, partly the unselfishness, and from this perfectly simple unostentatious unselfishness;
she was naturally a so naturally, not clever, not quick ~not
sh but as I should say, an artist -- that is without pose, or h snobbery: without any commonplaceness -- herself without effort -- it came too from her lac lack of pose, her lack of snobbery; and from the genuiness from something that was -- could I put my finger on it -- perfectly herself, individual. This unannmed quality -- the sensitivness to real things
this quality -- was queer, in the sister 3 of George and Gerald, who were so unmistakably opaque
and
thoroughly Philistine. conventional;
who had so innate a respect for the conventions and respectabilities. By some odd fling in her birth,
She she
had escaped
all taint of the Duckworth respectability. Philistinism. She had none of their shrewd commercial twinkle: middle class complacency. Instead of their little brown eyes that were that were so greedy and twinkling she
she had
hers were very large and rather a pale blue. They were
eyes;
dreamy, candid.
And She was without any of their instinctive worldliness. She was lovely too, in a far vaguer less perfect way than my mother. She reminded me always of some white
one of these those large white flowers -- elderblossom, cow parsley that one sees in the fields in June. (Perhaps my mothers name, laughing nickname
" -- Old Cow ",- --
suggests the cow parsley :) .
but Or, again a white faint moon in a pale blue sky suggests her. Or these those large white roses that have many petals and are semi transparent. She had beautiful fair hair, growing in horns over her forehead; and no colour in her face at all. She was very
Probably she was taught at home by governesses; and As for teaching -- she had perhaps a governess; went to classes . ;
She played
the violin, was taught by Arnold Dolmetch ; and played in Mrs Marshall's Marshalls orchestra. But there was a stoppage in her mind, a gentle impassivity about books and learning.
But as As Jack told me after her death, she thought herself so stupid as to be almost wanting; and said that she the rheumatic fever, which she had as a child, had (I remember the word)
" ' touched " '
her. But again, what I am what was remarkable, considering the minds of George and Gerald, Duckworth strain -- so boorish, so rustic, so Philistine -- is that however unintellectual simple
she was in brain, she was not, as their Georges sister might so well have been,
in the least a dull cheery ordinary m. English upper middle class girl: She had great charm, great sensibility; and if she had lived, would have been with rosy cheeks and bright brown eyes.
She was distinct. herself. She remains quite distinct in my mind. 4 And,
what What is odd, is that I cannot compare her , either in character or face with anyone I have ever known. any one else.
I have never seen anyone who looked like her; or was reminded me of her.;
What would sheshe would have looked like now
-or how would sheshe would have talked,.
in a room full of manyother people? I cannot see her,imagine;
orand that is true too of my mother,.
in that wayThey do not blend in the world of the living at all.

As she She was 18 nineteen when I was 6 six or 7, seven;
I used sometimesas a small child to be sent out with her, as chaperone ;, forand as a girl could then notnot then go about London alone.
So among Among
my earliest memories, is the memory of
trotting by her side when, I suppose, she was sent on errands; going out with her perhaps to shop, or to pay some call;
and the errand done, she would take me into to a shop and give me a glass of milk and little biscuits with sugar sprinkled on them. sprinkled with sugar on a marble table.
I think And sometimes we went about London in hansoms together.
But there were al But she lived of course downstairs in the
drawingroom; drawing room; pouring out tea; and there were many young men, it seemed to us, in love always when one dashed in for a second, sitting round her. Vaguely we knew that Arthur Studd was in love with her; and Ted Sanderson; and I think Richard Norton; and of course J Jim Stephen -- He . That great figure with the deep voice and the wild eyes would come wild and mad to the house in search of looking for
her; her, with his madness on him; and
rush up would burst
to into the nursery where we sat at breakfast, brandish and spear the bread on his sword stick.
We had mysterious orders and at one time we were told to go out by the back door, and if we met Jim we were to
tell him say that Stella was away. [TYPESCRIPT ENDS. MANUSCRIPT ONLY CONTINUES] Undoubtedly she must have been very attractive, taking my mother's place at her round tea table. She was always going out often dining out, and dancing, and there were her dance cards, the next day, with the pencil attached, and initials against all the dances, and sometimes a prize won at a cotillon. But how all the time, asked about as she was and admired and painted, there was only always her doglike devotion to my mother: remained anxious, always: her perpetual worry about her health. A kind of fight went on between them -- how how to save my mother; from being overtired. how to help her. It was not foolish; for during those years, the strain must have been very great; and the illness from which she died, came no doubt from the incessant activity -- the perpetual nursing, looking after, doing too much. Stella must have gues feared what was the truth -- my mother was worn out, I daresay unnecessarily: so that when she fell ill, her heart failed~. This dread was always I think behind Stella's mind.
